revision.comment: Persondata has been deprecated by [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)/Archive 122#RfC: Should Persondata template be deprecated and methodically removed from articles?|this RfC]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name= Isamu Mochizuki |birth_date=1906 |death_date= 1944 |birth_place= [[Saga Prefecture]], [[Japan]] |death_place= [[Roi-Namur]] |image=Isamu Mochizuki.jpg |caption=Mochizuki at the rank of [[Lieutenant Junior Grade]] |nickname= |allegiance= [[Empire of Japan]] |branch= [[File:Naval Ensign of Japan.svg|22x20px|border]] [[Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service]] ([[Imperial Japanese Navy|IJN]]) |serviceyears= 1925-1944 |rank= [[Lieutenant]] |commands= |unit= |battles=[[Second Sino-Japanese War]]
[[Pacific War]] |awards= |laterwork= }} {{Japanese name|Mochizuki}} '''Isamu Mochizuki''' ({{lang-ja|望月 勇}}; 1906 – 1944) was an officer and [[ace]] [[Fighter aircraft|fighter]] pilot in the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]] (IJN) during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] and the [[Pacific War|Pacific theater]] of [[World War II]]. In aerial combat over China and the Pacific, he was officially credited with destroying seven enemy aircraft. During his flying career, Mochizuki invented the half loop and roll technique used in dogfighting by Japanese fighter pilots. He was stranded on [[Roi-Namur]] Island with no aircraft to fly after the [[Battle of Kwajalein|American invasion]] on 6 February 1944. Mochizuki disappeared and was presumed killed in action in ground combat with the enemy. ==References== *{{cite book | last = Hata | first = Ikuhiko | authorlink = | author2 = Yasuho Izawa | author3 = Don Cyril Gorham (translator) | origyear = 1975 (original) | year = 1989 | edition = translated | chapter = | title = Japanese Naval Aces and Fighter Units in World War II | publisher = Naval Institute Press | location = [[Annapolis, Maryland]] | isbn = 0-87021-315-6 }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mochizuki, Isamu}} [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Japanese naval aviators]] [[Category:Japanese World War II flying aces]] [[Category:People from Saga Prefecture]] [[Category:Japanese military personnel killed in World War II]] {{Japan-mil-bio-stub}}
